questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of difficulty in walking for 5 months. His mother reports that he has trouble keeping his balance and walking without support. Over the past year, he has started to have difficulty seeing in the dark and his hearing has been impaired. Examination shows marked scaling of the skin on the face and feet and a shortened 4th toe. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the lower extremities and 4/5 in the upper extremities. Sensation to pinprick is symmetrically decreased over the legs. Fundoscopy shows peripheral pigment deposits and retinal atrophy. His serum phytanic acid concentration is markedly elevated. The patient's condition is most likely caused by a defect in which of the following cellular structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mitochondria are the primary site for the β-oxidation of unbranched long-chain, medium-chain, and short-chain fatty acids, but mitochondrial enzymes cannot break down branched-chain fatty acids (BCFAs) or very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). BCFAs (e.g., phytanic acid) must first undergo α-oxidation, a process that occurs exclusively in peroxisomes and removes the side groups from BCFA. Refsum disease, as seen here, is caused by defective α-oxidation of BCFAs in peroxisomes. Other processes that occur in peroxisomes include catalase enzyme reactions (e.g., ethanol catabolism), D-amino acid catabolism, and the synthesis of cholesterol, plasmalogen, and bile acids.

Similarly, VLCFAs must first be shortened to long-chain fatty acids by peroxisomal β-oxidation.

Other peroxisomal disorders include X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, which is caused by defective VLCFA β-oxidation and Zellweger syndrome, in which the cells completely lack peroxisomes and all peroxisomal functions are impaired.
Image Description:

Beta-oxidation of even-numbered fatty acids requires four enzymatic reactions, eventually yielding acyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA through cleavage of two carbons per cycle. This process is nearly identical in mitochondria and peroxisomes, except for some minor differences.

In peroxisomes, FADH2, which is generated during the first reaction, cannot undergo conversion to FAD through the respiratory chain but has to transfer its electrons onto oxygen. This reaction yields H2O2, which will subsequently be broken down into water and oxygen.

Moreover, beta-oxidation in peroxisomes does not allow for complete breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. Instead, carbon groups may only be cleaved off up to a chain length of at least eight remaining carbon atoms (octanyl-CoA). These fatty acids are then released into the cytosol and transferred to the mitochondria for complete breakdown. Acetyl-CoA generated in peroxisomes is also released into the cytosol to be used as substrate for other reactions, e.g., the mitochondrial citrate cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitochondria are the primary site for the β-oxidation of fatty acids. Further processes carried out by mitochondria include oxidative phosphorylation, the Krebs cycle, gluconeogenesis, heme synthesis, ketogenesis, and the urea cycle. Examples of diseases caused by defective mitochondrial function include systemic primary carnitine deficiency, medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, and mitochondrially inherited diseases (e.g., MELAS syndrome, Leber hereditary optic neuropathy). This patient presents with elevated phytanic acid concentrations; this branched-chain fatty acid can only be metabolized by α-oxidation, which occurs in a different cellular structure.

C) INCORRECT:

The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) is the major site for steroid hormone synthesis, drug metabolism (CYP450 system), and glucose-6-phosphatase activity. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, aromatase deficiency, and von Gierke disease are examples of impaired SER function. This patient has increased levels of phytanic acid, which is catabolized by a different cellular structure.

D) INCORRECT:

Myofilaments, which are composed of actin and myosin molecules, are functional and structural units of skeletal and cardiac muscle. Familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and Duchenne muscular dystrophy are associated with impaired myofilament function. A different cellular structure is defective in this patient with increased serum phytanic acid levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Proteasomes degrade ubiquitinated proteins and are involved in the elimination of viral components. Decreased proteasomal activity is implicated in the pathogenesis of certain cases of Parkinson disease, and increased proteasomal activity is responsible for tissue atrophy as well as certain cancers (e.g., multiple myeloma). This patient has increased levels of phytanic acid, which is catabolized by a different cellular structure.

F) INCORRECT:

Lysosomes contain enzymes that are involved in the hydrolytic breakdown of several biomolecules. Diseases caused by defective lysosomal function result in the accumulation of sphingolipids (e.g., Gaucher disease, Tay-Sachs disease), mucopolysaccharides (e.g., Hurler syndrome), glycoproteins (e.g., I-cell disease), or glycogen (e.g., Pompe disease). This patient has increased levels of phytanic acid, which is catabolized by a different cellular structure.
questions.hint: Phytanic acid is a branched-chain fatty acid that is normally converted to pristanic acid by α-oxidation. An autosomal recessive defect in α-oxidation is responsible for Refsum disease, which can manifest with scaly skin, shortening of the 4th toe, impaired vision (due to cataracts or retinitis pigmentosa), sensorineural hearing loss, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain in her ankle. She twisted her right ankle inward when walking on uneven ground the previous day. She describes the pain as 6 out of 10 in intensity. She is able to bear weight on the ankle and ambulate. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of gastroenteritis that lasted for two days and resolved spontaneously. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient drinks 8–10 beers each week and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She adheres to a strict vegetarian diet. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. Examination of the right ankle shows edema along the lateral aspect, pain with eversion, and tenderness to palpation on the lateral malleolus. The foot is warm to the touch and has dry skin. Pedal pulses are palpable. She has decreased sensation to light touch and vibration on the plantar surface of both feet and dorsal aspects of the first toe bilaterally. She has a full range of motion with 5/5 strength in flexion and extension of both first toes. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL


Hemoglobin A1c
8.1%


Leukocyte count
7200/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
82 μm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

4.0 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
24 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
1.2 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of the decreased sensation in this patient?

choices.text: Injury to the common peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A demyelinating polyneuropathy is characteristic of conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating neuropathy. In demyelinating neuropathies, motor abnormalities are usually as severe as or more severe than sensory abnormalities. This patient has a chronic axonal neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Common peroneal nerve injury can result in loss of sensation but the dorsal foot and the lateral calf are typically affected. Moreover, this condition is usually caused by traumatic injuries to the knee, fracture of the fibula, or constant pressure on the lateral knee, not ankle injuries. Foot drop and a slapping gait are also associated with common peroneal nerve injury. Sensory loss on the plantar surface of the feet without motor symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Although stretch injury to the sural nerve may be caused by lateral ankle injuries, this type of injury typically results in burning pain near the lateral malleolus and over the lateral aspect of the dorsal foot. The patient's loss of sensation in the plantar aspects of both feet and the dorsal aspects of both first toes is not consistent with damage to the sural nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency can cause bilateral peripheral neuropathy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more common in vegans and vegetarians who do not eat enough eggs or dairy products, and metformin therapy is a risk factor for vitamin B12 deficiency. However, vitamin B12 deficiency would also likely manifest with macrocytic anemia. The normal hemoglobin value with normal MCV and the presence of a specific risk factor in this patient make a different diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c > 6.5) have an increased risk of developing complications resulting from microvascular damage, which typically arises 5–10 years after disease onset. Complications include diabetic neuropathy, retinopathy, and nephropathy. This patient's loss of sensation on the feet bilaterally is consistent with diabetic neuropathy, which is typically a chronic axonal neuropathy and manifests with progressive symmetric sensory loss in the distal extremities (stocking-glove distribution). Patients may also report a burning sensation (dysesthesia) in the affected areas. In diabetic neuropathy, sensory abnormalities often appear before motor abnormalities (e.g., decreased ankle reflex).

This patient's elevated creatinine also suggests diabetic nephropathy, which occurs as a result of microvascular damage to the kidneys.

F) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency may occur in patients with alcohol use disorder and patients with dry beriberi (due to thiamine deficiency) may have symmetrical peripheral neuropathy of the distal extremities. Although this patient drinks more than the recommended amount, peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency usually includes both sensory and motor impairments. This patient's lack of motor impairment suggests a mechanism that predominantly affects sensory nerves.
questions.hint: This patient's sensory abnormalities are most likely the result of a nontraumatic peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive weakness and numbness. The symptoms started in her lower legs and gradually moved to her upper legs and arms. During the last 5 days, she has had headaches, and it has become more difficult to smile, talk, or drink. She has chronic hepatitis B infection and Graves disease. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her current medications include methimazole and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is alert and fully oriented. She has bilateral upper and lower facial paralysis. There is generalized muscle weakness in the extremities. Sensation to light touch is decreased throughout her body and is absent in her fingertips and toes. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elevated TSH and decreased FT4 levels

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-GM1 autoantibodies are seen in 10–25% of patients with CIDP. In the most typical form of CIDP, patients present with ascending symmetric sensory and motor deficits that progress over a period greater than two months. Although cranial nerve involvement (e.g., facial nerve palsy) is more common in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome, it may also occur in CIDP. CIDP is only rarely fatal; symptoms improve with treatment (IVIg, plasmapheresis, and/or glucocorticoids) over the course of months to years.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). Although generalized MG may present with limb and facial muscle weaknesses, the proximal muscles are more prominently affected. Symptoms typically worsen with increased muscle use throughout the day and improve with rest. Sensory symptoms would also not be present and deep tendon reflexes are usually preserved. In addition, patients would have some degree of ptosis and/or external ophthalmoplegia.
Image Description:

(1) Physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end-plate: synaptic vesicles filled with Acetylcholine (ACh) fuse with the presynaptic membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh to the nicotinic ACh receptors (AChR) → opening of receptor ion channel → influx of ions → depolarization, action potential, and contraction of the muscle → breakdown of ACh by cholinesterase and re-uptake in the motor end-plate.

(2) Impaired neuromuscular transmission in Myasthenia gravis: Antibodies compete with ACh for postsynaptic AChRs → ACh cannot bind → receptor ion channel does not open → no neuromuscular transmission

(3) Edrophonium test: Administration of edrophonium (cholinesterase inhibitor) → increase of ACh concentration in the synaptic cleft → increased binding of ACh to AChR → improved neuromuscular transmission.

C) INCORRECT:

20–30% of all cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in the US are preceded by infection with C. jejuni. Although GBS would present as an ascending paralysis and hyporeflexia (that may be accompanied by sensory deficits and bilateral facial nerve palsy), most cases have an acute onset of symptoms followed by recovery over a period of weeks. This patient's symptoms progressed over a period of 3 months.

D) INCORRECT:

ELISA is used as the initial screening test for patients with Lyme disease. Patients with early neuroborreliosis may develop bilateral facial nerve palsy, polyradiculopathy, and/or peripheral neuropathy, weeks to months after the initial infection. However, an ascending pattern of neurological abnormalities would be unusual. Also, other classical clinical features such as annular skin lesions (erythema migrans), fever, arthralgias, and/or signs of meningeal irritation (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting, neck stiffness) would precede the onset of muscle weakness and sensory deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can also result in bilateral, distal, symmetrical peripheral neuropathy as a result of axonal degeneration (which would cause hyporeflexia, weakness, paresthesias, and/or impairment of all forms of sensation including light touch). However, defects in higher mental functions (especially memory deficits), and other general physical findings (e.g., glossitis, cheilitis, anemia) would typically be present by the time motor deficits become apparent. Because this patient regularly consumes multivitamin tablets, vitamin B12 deficiency is unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevated TSH and decreased FT4 levels are seen in patients with hypothyroidism. Antithyroid drugs such as methimazole, which is used to treat Graves thyrotoxicosis, may inadvertently result in hypothyroidism. Although long-standing hypothyroidism can present with a form of distal, symmetric, glove-and-stocking sensory neuropathy (hypothyroid neuropathy) as well as a proximal myopathy that results in weakness, this patient has sensory and motor symptoms that involve both proximal and distal muscles. Also, other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, fatigue, dry skin and hair, menstrual irregularities) are not found in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

An elevated HbA1c is seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The most common neurological manifestation in patients with diabetes mellitus is a distal symmetrical sensory neuropathy characterized by distal sensory deficits. Although diabetic neuropathy may also result in diminished deep tendon reflexes (due to loss of the afferent pathway in the reflex), the decrease in reflexes would not be equal in all joints, and ankle reflexes would be affected more than patellar reflexes. Also, motor deficits and facial nerve palsy are not characteristic of diabetic neuropathy.

H) INCORRECT:

A positive serum botulinum neurotoxin would be expected in patients with botulism, which can present with symmetrical facial palsy, weakness in the limbs, and decreased deep tendon reflexes, however, sensory deficits are not a feature of botulism. Botulism would present with rapidly progressive, descending paralysis (unlike this patient's slowly progressive, ascending weakness). Also, there is no history of a wound or gastrointestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation) that would suggest this patient is at an increased risk of botulism.

I) INCORRECT:

A rapid plasma reagin test is used to screen patients for syphilis. The inconsistent use of protection can be a risk factor for STIs such as syphilis. Although patients with neurosyphilis may present with facial nerve palsy (due to meningeal syphilis), slowly progressive weakness (due to general paresis), or hyporeflexia (due to tabes dorsalis), these forms of neurosyphilis usually do not arise simultaneously and generally do not occur until years to decades after primary infection. Furthermore, the lack of other features of syphilis (chancre, lymphadenopathy, condylomata, syphilitic rash, etc.) in this patient's history makes this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: Progressive ascending motor and sensory deficits for greater than two months are characteristic of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He also reports that his stools have been drier and harder than usual. He has non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Two weeks ago, he completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength in the distal muscles of the lower extremities. Ankle reflex is 1+ bilaterally and knee reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased over the lower extremities. Serum glucose, creatinine, and electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Patients with neuropathy due to vincristine may have dysautonomic features, particularly constipation due to decreased gastrointestinal motility and, less frequently, orthostatic hypotension. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion, and in severe cases, changes in bowel movements. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes and usually involves dysautonomia. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, they are mild compared to the motor weakness. This patient's sensory symptoms are more predominant than his motor weakness. Also, dysautonomia in GBS usually involves tachycardia and hypertension/orthostasis rather than constipation. Finally, patients with GBS often complain of facial and/or oropharyngeal weakness, which is absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) causes mixed motor-sensory neuropathy, which is seen in this patient, CMT is hereditary and manifests in the third decade of life. Patients often have foot deformities such as pes cavus or hammer toes due to gradually increasing weakness of the lower extremity muscles. This patient has no family history of CMT, no evidence of musculoskeletal foot abnormalities, and is much older than would be expected at disease onset. Finally, CMT would not explain this patient's constipation.

F) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. Patients with hypothyroidism also often complain of constipation. However, weakness is rarely seen and occurs only in advanced cases. Moreover, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy and decreased intestinal motility.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of tingling in his feet and difficulty walking for the past 2 months. He says he has been tripping on sidewalks recently. He found a cut on his foot a month ago but has no knowledge of when it occurred. Physical examination shows muscle weakness in both lower extremities and reduced lower limb reflexes. Babinski sign is absent. There is reduced proprioception and sensation to touch in both feet and ankles. The patient has an ataxic gait and Romberg test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's paresthesia (tingling sensation) and symmetric distal sensory loss suggest polyneuropathy, which can be caused by axonal disorders (e.g., diabetes, alcohol use disorder, HIV, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) or demyelinating diseases (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome). His physical examination findings of sensory ataxia (as indicated by the positive Romberg test), lower motor neuron muscle weakness, and hyporeflexia further support this diagnosis (see "Differential diagnosis of impaired sensation and sensory ataxia" table).

Mononeuritis multiplex, which is distinct from polyneuropathy, is an asymmetric and asynchronous sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy involving ≥ 2 peripheral nerves in separate areas of the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, muscle weakness, and lower motor neuron signs may be seen in cauda equina syndrome. This syndrome, however, is more commonly associated with asymmetric muscle weakness rather than symmetric distal muscle weakness. Moreover, this patient does not have other features commonly associated with cauda equina, such as radicular pain, saddle anesthesia, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle weakness and lower motor neuron signs raise suspicion for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). However, ALS characteristically manifests with both lower and upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia). Moreover, ALS only affects the motor neurons; thus, sensory loss and ataxia would not be expected because sensory neurons are typically spared.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

D) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, sensory ataxia, and lower motor neuron muscle weakness and hyporeflexia may be seen in compressive myelopathy. However, lower motor neuron signs would only be expected at the level of the lesion with upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia) below the level of cord compression. Moreover, compressive myelopathy typically causes unilateral symptoms and it is often associated with other features such as back pain, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, sensory ataxia, and muscle weakness may be seen in subacute combined degeneration (SCD). However, SCD causes upper motor neuron weakness characterized by hyperreflexia and spasticity, whereas this patient presents with lower motor neuron muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. Moreover, the spinothalamic tract, which transmits pain, remains intact in individuals with SCD, while this patient did not feel the cut on his foot.

F) INCORRECT:

Loss of proprioception and touch, sensory ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes may raise suspicion for tabes dorsalis. However, tabes dorsalis is caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns and does not affect motor neurons, while this patient presents with muscle weakness. Moreover, he lacks other common features of tabes dorsalis such as episodes of lancinating pain in the extremities and back.
questions.hint: This condition is commonly seen in individuals with alcohol use disorder or poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressive numbness of her lower legs. She reports having difficulties sleeping because of a tingling sensation in her feet that keeps her awake. The symptoms began in the toes of both feet and have since progressed to her ankles and calves bilaterally. She says that she is concerned because her hands now also feel “clumsy.” She followed a vegan diet for a few weeks last year to lose weight but has since stopped. She has no known history of serious personal or family illness but has not seen a physician in several years. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/90 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the lower legs. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Sensation to pinprick and vibration is decreased throughout the lower extremities. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis are used in the diagnosis of conditions such as CNS infections (e.g., neuroborreliosis) and inflammatory demyelinating neuropathies (e.g., chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy; CIDP), which can manifest with polyneuropathy. Neuroborreliosis typically manifests with asymmetric polyneuropathy rather than the symmetrical involvement seen here, and motor symptoms are typically more prominent than sensory symptoms in CIDP. Another more prevalent cause is, therefore, more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies (NCSs) can determine whether neuropathy is caused by axonal degeneration (e.g., due to diabetes mellitus, alcohol use) or primary demyelination (e.g., due to chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, Guillain‑Barré-syndrome) and is usually indicated if the diagnosis remains unclear after initial diagnostic testing. NCS alone cannot provide a precise diagnosis, so another test is more appropriate for confirming the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) can be used to diagnose diabetes mellitus (DM), which is the most common cause of distal symmetric polyneuropathy. One of the major complications of long-term DM is microvascular damage, which typically arises 5–10 years after disease onset and can manifest as diabetic neuropathy. Diabetic polyneuropathy most commonly manifests with a progressive symmetric loss of sensation in the peripheral nerves of the distal extremities, typically in a “stocking-glove” distribution. Affected individuals may report a burning sensation and decreased muscle strength in the affected areas. Obesity is another risk factor for type 2 DM, so diabetic polyneuropathy is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

Other common causes of distal symmetric polyneuropathy include alcohol use and vitamin B12 deficiency, for which this patient has no risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum vitamin B12concentration is a part of the diagnostic evaluation of patients with polyneuropathy. Although vitamin B12 deficiency can manifest with symmetrical peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, it causes spastic paresis, rather than the flaccid paresis seen here. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as signs of anemia (e.g., conjunctival pallor, fatigue) and gait ataxia, and she currently follows a non-vegan diet, meaning that she is not at increased risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

A peripheral nerve biopsy can be used in the diagnostic evaluation of patients with polyneuropathy if underlying conditions such as vasculitis or amyloidosis are suspected. These conditions typically manifest with asymmetrical neuropathy rather than the symmetrical involvement seen here. Another less invasive test is more appropriate to confirm the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.
questions.hint: Progressive symmetric loss of sensation, dysesthesia, decreased muscle strength, and hyporeflexia in the distal lower extremities are consistent with polyneuropathy. Obesity is a risk factor for one of the most common forms of polyneuropathy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman has had slowly progressing numbness and tingling in the feet for the past 2 years. Examination shows distal, symmetric loss of pinprick sensation to the ankles and loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception in the toes. She has reduced reflexes at the ankles, but her strength and the rest of her neurologic examination is normal. Electrodiagnostic testing is notable for absent sural sensory-nerve action potentials.
Which one of the following blood tests is most appropriate in the initial evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A heavy metals screen is not appropriate because it would be an extremely rare cause of neuropathy without other symptoms or a history of substantial exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth genetic testing is not appropriate without a strong family history or other characteristic features.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

D) CORRECT:

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy presents with neurologic symptoms affecting both feet and slowly progressing proximally. Additional testing with nerve-conduction studies can confirm this diagnosis and refine it by determining whether the neuropathy is primarily axonal or demyelinating, sensory or motor, and symmetric or asymmetric.

Because diabetes mellitus is among the most common causes of distal symmetric polyneuropathy, a glycated hemoglobin test is indicated. Other tests that are appropriate in the evaluation of distal symmetric polyneuropathy are vitamin B12, methylmalonic acid, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and serum protein electrophoresis.

Key learning point: The diagnostic tests with the highest yield in the workup of patients with distal symmetric polyneuropathy are glycated hemoglobin or blood glucose, vitamin B12 and methylmalonic acid, and serum protein electrophoresis.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He has non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Two weeks ago, he completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ankle reflex is 1+ bilaterally and knee reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, this patient does not present with the characteristic ascending muscle weakness.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. However, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of tingling in his feet and difficulty walking for the past 2 months. He says he has been tripping on sidewalks recently. He found a cut on his foot a month ago but has no knowledge of when it occurred. Physical examination shows muscle weakness in both lower extremities and reduced lower limb reflexes. There is reduced sensation to touch in both feet and Romberg test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's paresthesia (tingling sensation) and symmetric distal sensory loss suggest polyneuropathy, which can be caused by axonal disorders (e.g., diabetes, alcohol use disorder, HIV, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) or demyelinating diseases (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome). His physical examination findings of sensory ataxia (as indicated by the positive Romberg test), lower motor neuron muscle weakness, and hyporeflexia further support this diagnosis (see "Differential diagnosis of impaired sensation and sensory ataxia" table).

B) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, muscle weakness, and lower motor neuron signs may be seen in cauda equina syndrome. This syndrome, however, is more commonly associated with asymmetric muscle weakness rather than symmetric distal muscle weakness. Moreover, this patient does not have other features commonly associated with cauda equina, such as radicular pain, saddle anesthesia, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle weakness and lower motor neuron signs raise suspicion for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). However, ALS characteristically manifests with both lower and upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia). Moreover, ALS only affects the motor neurons; thus, sensory loss and ataxia would not be expected because sensory neurons are typically spared.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

D) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, sensory ataxia, and lower motor neuron muscle weakness and hyporeflexia may be seen in compressive myelopathy. However, lower motor neuron signs would only be expected at the level of the lesion with upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia) below the level of cord compression. Moreover, compressive myelopathy typically causes unilateral symptoms and it is often associated with other features such as back pain, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of proprioception and touch, sensory ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes may raise suspicion for tabes dorsalis. However, tabes dorsalis is caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns and does not affect motor neurons, while this patient presents with muscle weakness. Moreover, he lacks other common features of tabes dorsalis such as episodes of lancinating pain in the extremities and back.
questions.hint: This condition is commonly seen in individuals with alcohol use disorder or poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has had slowly progressing numbness and tingling in the feet for the past 2 years. Examination shows distal, symmetric loss of pinprick sensation to the ankles and loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception in the toes. She has reduced reflexes at the ankles, but her strength and the rest of her neurologic examination is normal. Electrodiagnostic testing confirms distal symmetric polyneuropathy. Which one of the following blood tests is most appropriate in the initial evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A heavy metals screen is not appropriate because it would be an extremely rare cause of neuropathy without other symptoms or a history of substantial exposure.

B) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth genetic testing is not appropriate without a strong family history or other characteristic features.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

D) CORRECT:

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy presents with neurologic symptoms affecting both feet and slowly progressing proximally. Additional testing with nerve-conduction studies can confirm this diagnosis and refine it by determining whether the neuropathy is primarily axonal or demyelinating, sensory or motor, and symmetric or asymmetric.

Because diabetes mellitus is among the most common causes of distal symmetric polyneuropathy, a glycated hemoglobin test is indicated. Other tests that are appropriate in the evaluation of distal symmetric polyneuropathy are vitamin B12, methylmalonic acid, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and serum protein electrophoresis.

Key learning point: The diagnostic tests with the highest yield in the workup of patients with distal symmetric polyneuropathy are glycated hemoglobin or blood glucose, vitamin B12 and methylmalonic acid, and serum protein electrophoresis.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years, constipation, and urinary retention reports 6 months of worsening pain in the soles of his feet. He describes the pain as a burning sensation that is worse at night and is aggravated when clothing or sheets touch his feet. Neurologic examination reveals normal muscle strength and tone. The patient has diminished temperature and pinprick sensation in both feet. Vibration and proprioception are preserved. In addition to glycemic control, which one of the following medications is most appropriate to treat this patient's neuropathic pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of fluoxetine for the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is used for chronic therapy in trigeminal neuralgia, but data on the efficacy of carbamazepine for neuropathic pain due to diabetic neuropathy are inconclusive.

C) INCORRECT:

Moderate-quality data support the use of opioids (e.g., oxycodone) for alleviating neuropathic pain, but these medications are not considered first-line agents because of concerns about their safety and tolerability.

D) INCORRECT:

If a TCA were chosen for this patient, it should be one with fewer anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline, such as nortriptyline or desipramine. TCAs should ideally not be combined with other medications that have anticholinergic effects (such as muscle relaxants, diphenhydramine, and many antipsychotic medications) because the combination can increase the risk of adverse effects such as blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, and urinary retention. Care should also be taken if TCAs are combined with other sedating medications because of the risk of oversedation and falls.

E) CORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy can manifest as a painful, small-fiber neuropathy (as in this patient) or as susceptibility to entrapments, diabetic amyotrophy, or a length-dependent, large-fiber sensorimotor neuropathy. Improved glycemic control, physical exercise, balance therapy, and pharmacologic management of neuropathic pain can reduce symptoms, improve quality of life, and prevent further complications for patients with diabetic neuropathy.

First-line medications for neuropathic pain include:

• The anticonvulsants pregabalin and gabapentin
• The serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) duloxetine and venlafaxine
• The tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) amitriptyline

When deciding among these agents, clinicians should consider each medication’s adverse-effect profile and the individual patient’s comorbidities. In this case, the patient is currently experiencing constipation, erectile dysfunction, and severe urinary retention. The TCA amitriptyline has the potential to exacerbate all of these symptoms (given its anticholinergic activity) and is therefore not ideal for this patient. An SNRI such as duloxetine or venlafaxine might be a reasonable choice, although there have been reports of worsening urinary retention with these agents. Thus, gabapentin and pregabalin are better choices.

Gabapentin and pregabalin are structurally similar to one another, and trials have demonstrated that they have similar efficacy in reducing the pain associated with diabetic neuropathy. Of the two agents, only pregabalin is approved by the FDA for treatment of diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but either one would be acceptable for this patient. Caution is warranted with either medication, given the potential for sedating effects, misuse, and addiction.

Key learning point: Choice of first-line therapy for neuropathic pain should be governed by medication adverse-effect profiles and patient comorbidities.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He has a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin two weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. On examination, ankle reflexes are 1+ bilaterally and knee reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased in the lower extremities. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.

Key learning point: Vincristine commonly causes a symmetric, distal, mixed sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy, often presenting with numbness, tingling, and decreased reflexes in the lower extremities.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. However, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

E) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, this patient does not present with the characteristic ascending muscle weakness.
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of tingling in his feet and difficulty walking. He reports tripping on sidewalks recently. He noticed a cut on his foot a month ago but does not recall when it happened. On examination, there is muscle weakness in both lower extremities, reduced lower limb reflexes, and decreased sensation to touch in both feet. Romberg test is positive. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, sensory ataxia, and lower motor neuron muscle weakness and hyporeflexia may be seen in compressive myelopathy. However, lower motor neuron signs would only be expected at the level of the lesion with upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia) below the level of cord compression. Moreover, compressive myelopathy typically causes unilateral symptoms and it is often associated with other features such as back pain, which is not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of proprioception and touch, sensory ataxia, and absent deep tendon reflexes may raise suspicion for tabes dorsalis. However, tabes dorsalis is caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns and does not affect motor neurons, while this patient presents with muscle weakness. Moreover, he lacks other common features of tabes dorsalis such as episodes of lancinating pain in the extremities and back.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle weakness and lower motor neuron signs raise suspicion for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). However, ALS characteristically manifests with both lower and upper motor neuron signs (e.g., spastic paralysis, hyperreflexia). Moreover, ALS only affects the motor neurons; thus, sensory loss and ataxia would not be expected because sensory neurons are typically spared.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's paresthesia (tingling sensation) and symmetric distal sensory loss suggest polyneuropathy, which can be caused by axonal disorders (e.g., diabetes, alcohol use disorder, HIV, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease) or demyelinating diseases (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome). His physical examination findings of sensory ataxia (as indicated by the positive Romberg test), lower motor neuron muscle weakness, and hyporeflexia further support this diagnosis (see "Differential diagnosis of impaired sensation and sensory ataxia" table).

Key learning point: Polyneuropathy commonly causes symmetric distal sensory loss, sensory ataxia, muscle weakness, and hyporeflexia due to involvement of multiple peripheral nerves.

E) INCORRECT:

Sensory loss, muscle weakness, and lower motor neuron signs may be seen in cauda equina syndrome. This syndrome, however, is more commonly associated with asymmetric muscle weakness rather than symmetric distal muscle weakness. Moreover, this patient does not have other features commonly associated with cauda equina, such as radicular pain, saddle anesthesia, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.
questions.hint: This condition is commonly seen in individuals with alcohol use disorder or poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of gradually worsening numbness and tingling in her feet. On examination, there is distal, symmetric loss of pinprick sensation up to the ankles, and loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception in the toes. Ankle reflexes are reduced. Strength and the remainder of the neurologic examination are normal. Electrodiagnostic testing confirms distal symmetric polyneuropathy. Which one of the following blood tests is most appropriate in the initial evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Charcot-Marie-Tooth genetic testing is not appropriate without a strong family history or other characteristic features.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

C) INCORRECT:

A heavy metals screen is not appropriate because it would be an extremely rare cause of neuropathy without other symptoms or a history of substantial exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood tests that are not the most appropriate first-line tests in distal symmetric polyneuropathy but may be considered in the relevant clinical context include a comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, antinuclear antibody, and tests for Lyme disease, HIV infection, and syphilis. Testing for other vitamin levels (E, B1, and B6), a copper level, and a paraneoplastic panel are occasionally useful.

E) CORRECT:

Distal symmetric polyneuropathy presents with neurologic symptoms affecting both feet and slowly progressing proximally. Additional testing with nerve-conduction studies can confirm this diagnosis and refine it by determining whether the neuropathy is primarily axonal or demyelinating, sensory or motor, and symmetric or asymmetric.

Because diabetes mellitus is among the most common causes of distal symmetric polyneuropathy, a glycated hemoglobin test is indicated. Other tests that are appropriate in the evaluation of distal symmetric polyneuropathy are vitamin B12, methylmalonic acid, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and serum protein electrophoresis.

Key learning point: The diagnostic tests with the highest yield in the workup of patients with distal symmetric polyneuropathy are glycated hemoglobin or blood glucose, vitamin B12 and methylmalonic acid, and serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 62-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes, constipation, and urinary retention. He reports a 6-month history of worsening pain in the soles of his feet, describing it as a burning sensation that is worse at night and aggravated by contact with clothing or sheets. On neurologic examination, muscle strength and tone are normal. He has diminished temperature and pinprick sensation in both feet, while vibration and proprioception are preserved. In addition to glycemic control, which one of the following medications is most appropriate to treat his neuropathic pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy can manifest as a painful, small-fiber neuropathy (as in this patient) or as susceptibility to entrapments, diabetic amyotrophy, or a length-dependent, large-fiber sensorimotor neuropathy. Improved glycemic control, physical exercise, balance therapy, and pharmacologic management of neuropathic pain can reduce symptoms, improve quality of life, and prevent further complications for patients with diabetic neuropathy.

First-line medications for neuropathic pain include:

• The anticonvulsants pregabalin and gabapentin
• The serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) duloxetine and venlafaxine
• The tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) amitriptyline

When deciding among these agents, clinicians should consider each medication’s adverse-effect profile and the individual patient’s comorbidities. In this case, the patient is currently experiencing constipation, erectile dysfunction, and severe urinary retention. The TCA amitriptyline has the potential to exacerbate all of these symptoms (given its anticholinergic activity) and is therefore not ideal for this patient. An SNRI such as duloxetine or venlafaxine might be a reasonable choice, although there have been reports of worsening urinary retention with these agents. Thus, gabapentin and pregabalin are better choices.

Gabapentin and pregabalin are structurally similar to one another, and trials have demonstrated that they have similar efficacy in reducing the pain associated with diabetic neuropathy. Of the two agents, only pregabalin is approved by the FDA for treatment of diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but either one would be acceptable for this patient. Caution is warranted with either medication, given the potential for sedating effects, misuse, and addiction.

Key learning point: Choice of first-line therapy for neuropathic pain should be governed by medication adverse-effect profiles and patient comorbidities.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is used for chronic therapy in trigeminal neuralgia, but data on the efficacy of carbamazepine for neuropathic pain due to diabetic neuropathy are inconclusive.

C) INCORRECT:

Moderate-quality data support the use of opioids (e.g., oxycodone) for alleviating neuropathic pain, but these medications are not considered first-line agents because of concerns about their safety and tolerability.

D) INCORRECT:

If a TCA were chosen for this patient, it should be one with fewer anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline, such as nortriptyline or desipramine. TCAs should ideally not be combined with other medications that have anticholinergic effects (such as muscle relaxants, diphenhydramine, and many antipsychotic medications) because the combination can increase the risk of adverse effects such as blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, and urinary retention. Care should also be taken if TCAs are combined with other sedating medications because of the risk of oversedation and falls.

E) INCORRECT:

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of fluoxetine for the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of progressive bilateral leg weakness and tingling. He reports difficulty climbing stairs and walking. Three weeks ago, he had an episode of bloody diarrhea that resolved without treatment. On examination, he has bilateral lower extremity weakness (3/5 strength), absent ankle reflexes, and decreased sensation to light touch in his feet. Upper extremities show normal strength and reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcoholic polyneuropathy typically develops over months to years in patients with chronic alcohol use disorder and predominantly causes sensory symptoms with burning feet syndrome rather than acute progressive motor weakness.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy presents with symmetric weakness that progresses or has a relapsing-remitting course over more than 8 weeks, which is inconsistent with this patient's rapid 4-day progression.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient demonstrates the classic presentation of Guillain-Barré syndrome with acute onset of bilateral ascending weakness, areflexia, sensory involvement, and a preceding gastrointestinal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Diabetic polyneuropathy usually develops slowly over months to years in patients with poorly controlled diabetes and typically causes more sensory symptoms than motor weakness, particularly in the early stages.

E) INCORRECT:

Hereditary motor sensory neuropathy is a slowly progressive inherited condition that typically manifests before age 20 with distal muscle atrophy and associated foot deformities, not acute bilateral weakness in middle-aged adults.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of progressive burning pain and numbness that began in his toes and has gradually extended to his mid-shins bilaterally. He reports worsening difficulty walking due to unsteadiness. Physical examination reveals symmetrical distal sensory loss to light touch and vibration in both feet, absent ankle reflexes, and mild weakness of toe dorsiflexion. He has a history of consuming approximately 6-8 alcoholic beverages daily for the past 10 years. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used to treat inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathies such as CIDP. This patient's presentation with chronic alcohol use disorder and progressive distal sensory symptoms suggests a toxic-metabolic etiology rather than an inflammatory process.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is a first-line treatment for autoimmune polyneuropathies like CIDP. The patient's clinical features and alcohol history are inconsistent with an immune-mediated neuropathy that would respond to immunoglobulin therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has alcoholic polyneuropathy, which results from progressive peripheral nerve injury due to chronic alcohol use disorder. Thiamine supplementation addresses the underlying nutritional deficiency that contributes to nerve damage in alcoholic polyneuropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis removes circulating antibodies and immune complexes, making it useful for autoimmune conditions affecting peripheral nerves. It has no therapeutic benefit for alcoholic polyneuropathy, which is caused by chronic toxicity and malnutrition rather than immune-mediated mechanisms.

E) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin alone provides only symptomatic relief for neuropathic pain but does not address the underlying cause of alcoholic polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the ED with a 6-week history of numbness and tingling in both feet that has now progressed to involve his hands. He describes the sensation as "burning" and reports difficulty with fine motor tasks. Physical examination reveals distal sensory loss in a glove-and-stocking distribution, absent ankle reflexes, and mild weakness in finger extension bilaterally. His symptoms began symmetrically and have been slowly progressive. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Urgent neurology consultation in the ED

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has a typical presentation of symmetric distal polyneuropathy with slow progression over weeks in the setting of diabetes. This classic presentation does not require urgent specialty evaluation and can be appropriately managed with primary care follow-up for outpatient laboratory workup to evaluate common causes and initiate treatment of the underlying condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent neurology consultation is indicated for atypical presentations such as rapid progression, asymmetric symptoms, or primarily motor dysfunction. This patient's symmetric distal sensory pattern with slow progression does not warrant emergent specialty evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

While neurology referral may eventually be appropriate, the typical presentation and slow progression do not require immediate electrodiagnostic studies. Primary care evaluation with initial laboratory workup is the appropriate first step for this classic polyneuropathy pattern.

D) INCORRECT:

Inpatient admission is not indicated for this stable, chronic presentation. The patient has no acute complications or rapid deterioration that would require hospitalization for evaluation or treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Pain management referral alone does not address the need for diagnostic evaluation of the underlying polyneuropathy. While pain control may eventually be needed, determining and treating the underlying cause should be the initial focus.
